Notes: No new policy. Schools are teaching in-person with certain precautions. Ex. teachers wearing masks, students wearing masks.  On 13 January 2022, National Cabinet agreed to a national framework to promote a nationally consistent approach to the ongoing delivery of high-quality education for all students during COVID-19. This framework ensure all schools are open and be able to stay open, with as little disruption from COVID-19 as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322080316/https://www.dese.gov.au/covid-19/schools  https://archive.ph/mwzii

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are now in effect. More widely, proof of vaccination requirements remain in place for certain businesses and venues (ex. hospitality).     Western Australia Level 2 measures are that:  The 2sqm rule, a maximum of 150 patrons (not including staff) where food and beverages are served, with seated service only, applies to high risk venues including the following:  - Hospitality venues  -Fitness venues  -Entertainment venues (for seated entertainment venues â see below)  -Galleries and museums  -Places of worship  -Hairdressers, beauty services, spas, saunas, tattoo and massage parlours  -Nightclubs     -Convention centres and function centres  -Community, recreation or youth centre facilities  -2sqm rule, up to a limit of 500 patrons, applies to certain other public venues including Perth Zoo, outdoor amusement parks, swimming pools and libraries.  -50 % capacity for specified entertainment venues with fixed seating that faces forward, like cinemas, theatres and concert halls (with seated service only) is permitted as an alternative to the 2sqm rule and 150 patron limit.  50 % capacity for major stadiums with fixed seating, such as Optus Stadium, RAC Arena, HBF Stadium (main area) and HBF Park (with seated service only).    Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  â¢	everywhere indoors, other than in the home  â¢	when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  â¢	at major stadiums and organised public gatherings  â¢	at hospitals and residential aged care or disability care facilities    https://archive.ph/4RVp5

As of 31 March the majority of the Level 2 health measure in place were rolled back to Level 1 (Western Australia region). More widely, proof of vaccination requirements remain in place for certain businesses and venues (ex. hospitality) nationally.     Western Australia Level 1 measures are that:  Density and capacity limits  The 2 square metre (2sqm) rule and 500 patron capacity limit applies to:  -Licensed hospitality venues  -Nightclubs    Convention centres and function centres  The 2sqm rule also applies to:  -Fitness venues  -Entertainment venues  -Galleries and museums  -Places of worship  -Hairdressers, beauty services, spas, saunas, tattoo and massage parlours  -Perth Crown Complex  -Community, recreation or youth centre facilities.    Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  - everywhere indoors, other than in the home  - when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  - at hospitals and residential aged care or residential disability care facilities.    https://archive.ph/kUJ4m

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are in effect which allows for safe quarantine-free travel into WA from interstate and overseas, with vaccination and testing requirements on arrival.    Interstate arrivals into WA must:  - have a registered G2G Pass  - be triple dose vaccinated, if eligible; and  - undertake a rapid antigen test (RAT) on arrival (within 12 hours and report any positive result)    Other regional restrictions vary but are more lenient.     https://archive.ph/4RVp5

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are in effect which has eased travel but enforces restrictions against travel to Aboriginal communities. To help keep remote Aboriginal communities safe from COVID-19, there are strict travel restrictions in place. Tourists and travellers are not allowed to enter. Vaccination status does not affect this restriction.     Under the WA Governmentâs Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  - providing essential services and supplies  - going to work or school there  - entering for family or cultural reasons  - delivering a community program or activity  - entering in an emergency.  These people cannot enter a community if they have COVID-19 or symptoms of COVID-19, or if they are waiting for a test result or have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.  - Travellers can drive through a remote Aboriginal community only if they do not stop or come into contact with any person in the community.  - Police have the power to enforce the travel restrictions, and fines of up to $50,000 can be issued.    Other AUS regional restrictions vary but are more lenient.     https://archive.ph/8tKNt

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     Fully vaccinated Australian citizens, permanent residents, and eligible visa holders can travel to and from Australia without needing to apply for a travel exemption. All other people who are not fully vaccinated require a travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to applicable state and territory quarantine requirements.     The Australian government requires all individuals traveling to or transiting through Australia, with limited exceptions, to provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test at time of check-in.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084811/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084731/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      Under current restrictions, some people cannot visit a residential aged care facility. This includes people who:    - have returned from overseas in the past 14 days  - have been in contact with someone confirmed to have COVID-19 in the past 14 days  - are unwell, including with a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory illness (such as a cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  - need isolation or quarantine (unless directed by and managed per the direction of the local public health unit).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

As of 31 March in the Western Australia region "Level 1" measures are now in effect. Part of these restrictions include external visitor restrictions for residential aged and disability care facilities:  - 2 visitors permitted per resident patient per day  - Masks must be worn by staff and visitors indoors and outdoors  - Proof of vaccination applies for visitors    National policy still in place outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://archive.ph/kUJ4m  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the first Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

With the rise of Omicron in March, schools moved back to online learning with some exemptions granted for key exam years. The Brunei Government announced on 28 March 2022 that child care centers, kindergartens, secondary schools, colleges, and sixth form centers will resume classroom learning on either 4 April or 5 April, pending the sighting of the moon on 1 April 2022, which will determine the first day of Ramadan (a public holiday). Primary schools with less than 50 pupils will be allowed to reopen. Other schools must wait until the Covid-19 vaccination program for children aged 5-11 rolls out.    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)    Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)   Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

As part of Bruneiâs National COVID-19 Recovery Framework, Brunei moved to its âearly endemic phaseâ on 15 December until 15 April 2022. Business premises including restaurants, fitness facilities, markets and cinemas can open at 75% capacity or 300 people, whichever is the lower number. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people." No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    However, night-time curfews are still in force and extended to 14th February, with the curfew remaining but shortened to 12 to 4am from 15 January. Up to this date, Brunei's night-time curfews remain from 10pm to 4am. Brunei?went into lockdown on 7 August 2021. Although measures have since relaxed, there are still restrictions in place. There is a daily curfew between 12am and 4am which will be lifted on 1 April 2022. Masks are mandatory for everyone over 2 years old when in public places, but may be removed when you are drinking or eating, or if you are exercising. There are financial penalties for not adhering to mask guidelines. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).    https://archive.ph/PKNGT

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 31 March. (See https://archive.ph/agN4c)    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar,    Is a curfew in place?  Yes.  The stay at home directive is extended until February 14, 2022 (sic. March 14, 2022), but shortened from 12am to 4am.    Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No.  The government has not restricted intercity or interstate travel.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO
Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No.  The government has not restricted intercity or interstate travel.    https://archive.ph/w7nh2

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the [US Embassy in Brunei's website](https://archive.ph/dgjiE), archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

Royal Brunei Airlines has suspended most of its routes until June 30, 2022, with limited scheduled service continuing to Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, London, Manila, Melbourne, and Singapore only.   Essential outbound travel is allowed for citizens and permanent residents, by obtaining a PMO exit travel approval, who have received two doses of vaccination within 14 days to three months (and no longer than six months) prior to departure or for those who have received a booster dose.   Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.    https://archive.ph/w7nh2

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." Ministry of Health 1 Apr 22:  We now leave it to you to assess your own level of risk and decide to continue to take measures such as masking and social distancing. If you are at higher risk of severe disease should you get infected with COVID-19, we strongly recommend that you continue to wear a mask in public, particularly in crowded indoor spaces. The lifting of masking and other mandates, and easing of travel restrictions, is NOT a sign that the risk of outbreak and resurgence of COVID-19 is over. Individuals who are currently receiving the first and second dose of the COVID-19 vaccines will be administered with the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. The Ministry of Health and Medical Services reminds the public that currently there are no stocks of AstraZeneca vaccine in the country therefore, Pfizer is offered for primary series.    Additionally, both, Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are administered as booster doses to individuals aged 18 years and above. Individuals become eligible for the booster dose 5 months after they have received their 2nd dose.  Eligible individuals are encouraged to get their booster doses to maintain maximum and longer-lasting protection against severe consequences from COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307084939/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology has issued Circular No. 2/2022 on Discretion Towards the Implementation of the four-minister joint decree on schooling during the COVID-19 pandemic. The circular stipulates that those areas where PPKM level 2 are implemented may limit face-to-face schooling to 50% of the class capacity.    The government is mulling over stopping its policy of opening schools to 100% physical attendance. The news comes after a proposal from Jakartaâs Governor Anies Baswedan to the Central Government over its 100% school reopening policy for one month due to concerns over the Omicron variant of COVID-19. In Java and Bali, areas under level 4 protocols allow non-essential and essential industries to operate on-site at 25 and 50-percent capacity, respectively. Level 3 restrictions permit on-site workforce caps of up to 50 percent in most industries and 75 percent in export-oriented industries. Level 2 curbs allow all sectors to operate on-site at a maximum of 75-percent capacity. Under level 1 protocols, all sectors can run at full capacity.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

Minister of Home Affairs Tito Karnavian has issued Minister of Home Affairs Instruction (Inmendagri) No. 8/2022 on the prevention and handling of COVID-19 during the Mandalika MotoGP in Pertamina Mandalika International Street Circuit, West Nusa Tenggara 2022. The instruction stipulates a maximum of 100,000 on-site viewers, and a maximum capacity of 10 percent for the festival grounds. All on-site viewers, racers, attendants, crew and officials must also be already fully vaccinated and present a negative PCR test result that is valid for 2x24 hour or a negative Antigen test result that is valid for 1x24 hour    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

Long-distance travellers to and from Java and Bali are required to show proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 (RT-PCR or rapid antigen) test result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220317213636/https://southeastasiabackpacker.com/covid19-indonesia-travel-restrictions/     Individuals utilizing public transport must comply with large-scale social distancing policies that include the mandatory use of face masks and maintaining appropriate physical separation. Due to social distancing measures, seating/standing space on public transport may be limited and schedules may be reduced.    https://archive.ph/cZ5qg

All long-distance travelers to and from Java and Bali using all modes of transport are required to show the vaccination card report (first dose is acceptable) and a certificate of negative RT-PCR test or rapid antigen test.    Travelers using air transportation who fly between airports on the island of Java and Bali, including flights from or to Java and Bali are required to present vaccination record (first dose is acceptable) and negative RT-PCR test which was obtained within 48 hours and fill-up e-HAC (Electronic Health Alert Certificate) prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220327182340/https://kemlu.go.id/losangeles/en/news/11727/update-indonesia-travel-restrictions

As of March 9, officials have lifted the pre-departure testing rule for fully vaccinated domestic travelers on air, sea, and land routes. Unvaccinated travelers must provide a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours or a RAT test taken within 24 hours before departure. All air and sea travelers must also register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel. Officials advise passengers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

The COVID-19 Task Force has issued Circular No. 11/2022 and Circular No. 12/2022 that relaxes the health protocol for, respectively, domestic and international travel during the COVID-19 pandemic. Circular No. 11/2022 stipulates that domestic travelers who are completely vaccinated are no longer required to show a negative Antigen or PCR Test Result. Meanwhile, Circular No. 12/2022 stipulates that Indonesians and foreigners travelling from abroad who have been completely vaccinated will only be required to quarantine for 1x24 hours. These circulars take effect starting March 8, 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220326153025/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

The Ministry of Finance has issued Minister of Finance Regulation No. 3/PMK.03/2022 on Tax Incentive for Taxpayers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Regulation stipulates the extension of the prevailing tax incentive on income tax, import tax on certain importers, as well as final income tax for construction services. The import tax incentive is effective until June 30, 2022, while the income tax and the construction services final income tax incentives is effective until the June 2022 tax period.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

On March 7, priority measures for the following 18 metropolitan areas or prefectures continue until March 21 2022:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kagawa, Kumamoto, Hokkaido, Aomori, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Ishikawa, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo.  Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy. Schools continue to remain open with increased vigilence in all prefectures. Students will be attending in-person schooling on alternative days to reduce capacity on school grounds for: Nagoya city and Shinjuku ward. Schools also have the jurisdiction to close in the event of an outbreak.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    No other changes to school measures. All schools and extracurricular activities continue to be open with precautions in place. Schools may also have the power to temporarily close should there be an outbreak.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

On March 7, priority measures for the following 18 metropolitan areas or prefectures continue until March 21 2022:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kagawa, Kumamoto, Hokkaido, Aomori, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Ishikawa, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo.  Meanwhile, on March 6, measures for the folloiwng 13 prefectures are lifted:   Fukushima, Niigata, Nagano, Mie, Wakayama, Okayama, Hiroshima, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Miyazaki and Kagoshima.    No change to previous policy. The following measures apply to all prefectures under priority measures: Require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table and may serve groups greater than 4 if proof of vaccination is shown. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  For all those in priority measures, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063439/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021127.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    No further restrictions for workplaces are in place. However, telework to reduce contact and infection precautions including hand hygiene and better ventilation continue to be encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

On March 1st, Japan begins increasing the maximum number of foreigners entering the country from the current 3,500 to 5,000. Entry without an approved VISA sponsored by a workplace or a school continues to be restricted. Travel for leisure and tourism continues to be restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060747/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220301/k10013506061000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303111053/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501761000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307065250/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The government is looking to expedite the entry for authorized foreigners into Japan (i.e. those with valid travel VISAs for business or education purposes). Japan is looking to permit 150,000 foreign students to enter the country by the end of May 2022.  On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html

On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.  However, travel remains restricted to Visa holders and travel for tourism purposes continue not to be permitted entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020344/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220316/k10013534891000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322021949/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Mar 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.  For note, "Elementary School Leave Subsidy" is a system to support parents who have to take a break from work when the school or nursery school where their children attend is closed or closed due to the influence of COVID. Deadline have been extended until the end of June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055840/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063810/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220226/k10013502281000.html

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Mar 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055840/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063810/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Ehime prefecture has been conducting free PCR and antigen tests across 80 pharmacies and clinics for asymptomatic people beginning January, expected to run until the end of March. However, due to supply issues, testing kits are becoming scarce and thus asymptomatic testing will be suspended beginning week of March 7.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307061753/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220304/k10013513511000.html

Vaccinations for children 5-11 continue to be administered.  Third doses continue for the elderly and employees of small to medium size businesses. The government reports that about 70% of the elderly population in Japan had received their third doses by the end of February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311033316/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220308/k10013519761000.html

On Mar 23, the Lao Ministry of Education and Sports issued a notice closing face-to-face classes at primary schools across the country. This involves both private and state-run schools, preschools and Grade 1-4. Affected classes will switch to remote learning.   Students in all higher grades will continue with face-to-face learning but all education institutions must comply with the 10 measures and 40 recommendations laid down by the education ministry to prevent the spread of Covid.  The notice came into effect the same day and will continue to be in effect until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221614/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Education_ministry59.php    https://archive.ph/VNyCI

Entertainment venues such as karaoke bars, tourism sites, night markets, food gardens, pubs, cinemas, snooker halls, shopping malls, and internet cafes must close.  The following entities are allowed to operate with adherence to COVID-19 prevention measures:  Banks and Other Financial Institutions  Gas Stations and Convenience Stores  Hospitals and Medical Centers  Hotels and Resorts  Medical Emergency Services  Pharmacies  Postal Service  Supermarkets, Agricultural and Fresh Markets  Telecommunication, Electricity, and Water Supply Providers  Restaurants and Coffee Shops    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus

Entertainment venues such as karaoke bars, tourism sites, night markets, food gardens, pubs, cinemas, snooker halls, shopping malls, and internet cafes must close.  Indoor and outdoor sports centers such as fitness centers, gyms, sports fields, swimming pools, and other sports venues may reopen, provided they abide by the COVID-19 prevention measures.  Garment factories and other types of factories must close. However, if the factory can guarantee that there is no risk of COVID-19, consideration for continuing operations will be made.  Retailers and food vendors may also open for the sale and delivery of food and daily necessities, provided they abide by the COVID-19 prevention measures.  The following entities are allowed to operate with adherence to COVID-19 prevention measures:  Massage parlors, spas, beauty parlors  banks and other financial institutions  gas stations and convenience stores  hospitals and medical centers  hotels and resorts  medical emergency services  pharmacies  postal service  supermarkets, agricultural and fresh markets  telecommunication, electricity, and water supply providers  restaurants and coffee shops    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Travel is prohibited in localized areas (red zones) where community transmission of COVID-19 is present.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
All passengers must be fully vaccinated to access passenger transport services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214054835/https:/www.covid19.gov.la/index.php?r=site%2Fdetail&id=960

In Vientiane Capital region and any province with community spread, Traffic curfew between 11:30 pm to 5 am except for ambulances, fire trucks, rescue teams, those authorized by the task force, on-duty officials, and vehicles transporting goods, food, and medical supplies. During these hours, people must stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A curfew is in place in Vientiane Capital region and any province with community spread from 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM    https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Restrictions are in place for provinces with community transmission. Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Travel is prohibited in localized areas (red zones) where community transmission of COVID-19 is present.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220328051052/https:/la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

While the Government of Laos is not issuing tourist visas at this time, those who currently hold or are issued valid multiple entry long-term visas (i.e. work or diplomatic visa) may return to Laos, though permission to enter is also subject to additional requirements. To avoid a second 14-day quarantine, foreign citizens who intend to travel to another province after arriving in Vientiane must submit the following documents to relevant officials: a travel itinerary, evidence of a 14-day quarantine, and authorization from the National Taskforce for COVID-19 Prevention and Control. If these documents are not submitted, foreign citizens should expect to do a 14-day quarantine in Vientiane and a 14-day quarantine at another province â their final destination. All travelers are screened for COVID-19 at the airport on arrival and before departing Laos.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a recommendation to ease restrictions on entry to Laos for Lao nationals and foreigners holding labor visas (LA-B2), spouse visas (SP-3), or other types of multiple entry visas.  Upon arrival in Laos, a 48-hour quarantine period following an RT-PCR test for foreign residents arriving in Laos will remain in place, after which seven-day home isolation is authorized.    https://archive.ph/WfHQX    https://archive.ph/DgQyo

The government includes income tax exemption for both civil servants and employees of the private sector with income less than 5 million kips per month for three months; profit tax exemption for microenterprises with annual income between 50â400 million kip for three months; duty fee exemption for imports of goods to be used towards the outbreak; and deferral of road tax payments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315182601/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There is a COVID 19 website    https://web.archive.org/web/20211117015306/https:/www.covid19.gov.la/index.php/

The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:  All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The contact tracing is limited only to positive people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Parties, conferences, and gatherings of any kind continue to be prohibited, except for funerals and certain religious activities such as alms offerings.  Such exempted events still must adhere to all previously announced COVID-19 prevention measures including conducting temperature checks, maintaining social distancing of at least one meter, wearing masks, and using hand sanitizer.  Those who violate this order, may be placed in a state quarantine center or quarantine hotel, and may be fined.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

People must wear facemasks and observe social distancing rules when in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214004322/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/laos-officials-continue-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-feb-3-update-41

The Laos national vaccination program started in November 2020 using the AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Pfizer-BioNTech, and Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) vaccines. And they have broad availability and are funded by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315182601/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Vaccination priority groups include healthcare workers, people aged 60 and above, people with underlying health conditions, pregnant women, and essential workers such as schoolteachers, as outlined in the National Deployment and Vaccination Plan. Adolescents aged 12 to 17 years are also being prioritized for vaccines.    A nationwide vaccination programme for children aged 6 and over against Covid-19, started Feb 21, 2022.    The Ministry of Health plans to offer fourth doses of Covid-19 vaccines to healthcare workers and people at risk of serious illness starting next month, hoping to shield vulnerable groups from infection with the Omicron variant.    Currently 5 types of vaccines are available in Laos - Sinopharm, Astra Zeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer and Sputnik.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220214054412/https:/www.phnompenhpost.com/international/laos-health-ministry-targets-8725-covid-shots-end-2022    https://web.archive.org/web/20220202225727/https:/la.usembassy.gov/the-united-states-provides-1698840-doses-of-the-pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-to-lao-pdr/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325222358/https:/www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2022/02/22/laos-govt-to-expedite-covid-19-vaccination-programme    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221409/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Health_phet.php

The vaccines will be primarily used to vaccinate those who are at risk of severe Covid-19 but have not yet received all the recommended doses. Priority groups include healthcare workers, people aged 60 and above, people with underlying health conditions, pregnant women, and essential workers such as schoolteachers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315184446/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/international/laos-health-ministry-targets-8725-covid-shots-end-2022

Vaccination is being prioritized for the elderly. Fourth Covid-19 vaccinations will be offered to frontline workers, people with immunodeficiency or chronic disease, and people over the age of 60.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325221409/https:/www.vientianetimes.org.la/freeContent/FreeConten_Health_phet.php

In response to the changes in the epidemic situation in Tanzhou, the DSEDJ announced that school staff and students of higher education institutions and non-tertiary education schools who have resided in Tanzhou in the past 14 days will suspend face-to-face classes from March 1 (Tuesday), and students will study at home instead. Their assessments will be handled flexibly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312002849/https://www.gcs.gov.mo/detail/en/N22BbSwk98;jsessionid=79C1610E3A58944880CBB2FBAFD205AB.app03?0

The DSEDJ announced that since March 7 (Monday), Macao students and teaching staff of tertiary education institutions and non-tertiary education schools residing in Tanzhou town of Zhongshan will return to face-to-face teaching in Macao. However, the DSEDJ once again calls on parents to vaccinate their children aged 3 or above as soon as possible to protect the health and safety of their children.    https://archive.ph/cEGk9

No change in policy. Remarks: Teachers and students who live in Zhuhai Nanping can resume face-to-face classes from April 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220401125443/https://portal.dsedj.gov.mo/webdsejspace/internet/Inter_main_page.jsp?id=88237

On March 10, the government will allow salons to reopen since it was ordered to close on February 10 but venues including gyms, bars, and entertainment venues will remain closed, and the existing restrictions will be kept in place.   Visit record is required for entry into workplaces of public entities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312004550/https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/things-to-do/things-you-need-to-know-about-hong-kongs-social-distancing-restrictions

No workplace closing. The government recommends wearing mask constantly and implement various epidemic prevention measures, maintain distance, and avoid crowds gathering.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220401134607/https://www.ssm.gov.mo/docs/16943/16943_6e3a3d0a615e4c0aa1b795d29632b11e_000.pdf

No policy changes.    Entertainment venues, which had been closed from 6 October 2021 are now allowed to re-open, but remain affected by other Covid-19 policies. This includes cinemas, theatres, nightclubs and others involving large, concentrated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211106163438/https://www.ggrasia.com/macau-entertainment-venues-to-reopen-from-oct-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220401134659/https://www.ssm.gov.mo/docs/20141/20141_47057ba0be1e4874b06245b091222e97_000.pdf
Public gatherings have been restricted to a maximum of 2 people (members of the same household are exempt).    https://archive.ph/yk8UE

No policy changes.   Mask wearing requirements: Macau requires the wearing of a face mask in many public settings including, banks, casinos, and on public transportation. Land rental: Exemption of land rental under MOP$100.00.  Property tax: Standard deduction of MOP$3,500.00 on property tax. If the taxpayer is two or more natural persons (individuals), its property tax can be similarly deducted the aforementioned amount if and only if one of them is permanent resident of Macao SAR. If the taxpayer is a legal person, individual commercial entrepreneur or non-resident of Macao SAR, it is not eligible for such deduction.     Salaries tax: 30% exemption on salaries tax and the exemption allowance for its assessment in 2022 is MOP$144,000.00. In case of the following situation: employer should withhold tax from causal worker whose daily salary is over MOP$640.00 or employee whose monthly salary is over MOP$16,000.00. Please refer to the Simulation Calculation disposal in website of FSB. In addition, exemption allowance for part-time and employee who are aged 65 or above or with permanent disability level of or above 60%, is adjusted to MOP$198,000.00.    https://archive.ph/4NMvV

With decreasing Covid-19 cases across Myanmar, public schools, private schools, and monastic education schools in all the townships except 46 in nine regions and states close to border areas were reopened starting on November 1.  No further policy could be found since the reopening.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135128/https://elevenmyanmar.com/news/yangon-schools-see-just-over-80000-of-over-500000-enrollees-on-reopening-day

COVID restrictions remain in place. Some restaurants have reopened but some are still closed or only offer take away or delivery. Some shopping centres require customers to register their details upon entry. You must wear a face mask in all public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135812/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus

The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M.  In Rangoon, the curfew was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M.  In Rangoon, the curfew was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some domestic flights have resumed.   Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has resumed but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are limited due to the ongoing civil unrest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

During COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in Burma, residents may only leave their residence to travel to/from work, to buy groceries, or for medical treatment.  A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.  Authorities set up checkpoints in Rangoon and elsewhere to verify travelers are on the road for permitted reasons.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? â YES   Some domestic flights have resumed.   Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has resumed but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are limited due to the ongoing civil unrest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Authorities have extended international travel restrictions, including a ban on entry for most international travelers and the suspension of on-arrival visas and e-visas, through March 31.  Burmese authorities will no longer allow international commercial passenger flights to land at any airport in Burma.  This suspension will last until further notice.  All landing permissions previously granted are suspended.  Exceptions apply to ârelief flights, all-cargo flights, medical evacuation flights and special flights specifically approved by the Department of Civil Aviation.â All foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens and all diplomats and U.N. officials, are required to present laboratory evidence of absence of COVID-19 infection issued no more than 72 hours prior to the date of travel before boarding any airline destined to Burma. U.S. citizens have reported being asked to submit to a COVID-19 health examination as part of their in-country Burmese visa renewal process.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325142002/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/myanmar-officials-extend-covid-19-international-entry-restrictions-through-march-31-update-51  https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Household support- In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec. Transferring MMK 400 billion to Myanmar Economic Bank to establish a COVID 19 Fund to provide soft loans to affected businesses (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at 1 percent interest for one year. The repayment term was extended by six months; (ii) provision of MMK 600 billion loans to farmers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Household support- In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec. Transferring MMK 400 billion to Myanmar Economic Bank to establish a COVID 19 Fund to provide soft loans to affected businesses (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at 1 percent interest for one year. The repayment term was extended by six months;   Provision of MMK 600 billion loans to farmers.  Waiver of specific goods tax, customs duty, and commercial tax on critical medical supplies and products related to the prevention, control, and treatment of COVID-19;   Reduction of the income tax rate by half for real estate purchase, construction, access and establishment of new business on income up to 3 billion kyat     https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Ministry of Health and Sports website has public announcements, news on COVID 19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325143427/https://www.mohs.gov.mm/

Rapid Response Teams (RRT) were organized in order to respond 24 hours for emergency cases and the testing policy is open to all residents. People need to contact the phone numbers of respective RRTs.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220325143549/https://www.mohs.gov.mm/Main/content/annouancement/list?pagenumber=1&pagesize=9
There is comprehensive contact tracing of the majority of positive cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325143549/https://www.mohs.gov.mm/Main/content/annouancement/list?pagenumber=1&pagesize=9

During COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in Burma, residents may only leave their residence to travel to/from work, to buy groceries, or for medical treatment.  A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Authorities have authorized COVID-19 vaccinations for use in Burma, including the CoronaVac, AstraZeneca, CoviShield, Pfizer BioNTech, Comirnaty, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson, Moderna, Sinopharm, Sputnik, and Covaxin vaccines. These vaccines are broadly given to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups, and Elderly groups, and other essentials.   Myanmar government established the COVID-19 Vaccination Fund to procure vaccines. The fund is initially contributed US$250 million and MMK 1,000 million kyats by the government and calls for donation of people and organizations in the country and abroad.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325135821/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No measures

A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old).    https://archive.ph/UA9We

A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old). All the vaccination activities are recorded and reported in the Vaccine Management Information System-VMIS. Therefore, the COVID-19 vaccination program in Myanmar is currently active for 24 groups and is in a neutral manner without any discrimination, leaving no one behind irrespective of their ethnicity, religion, gender, socio-economic status, or political affiliation.     https://archive.ph/UA9We

Myanmar government established the COVID-19 Vaccination Fund to procure vaccines. The fund is initially contributed US$250 million and MMK 1,000 million kyats by the government and calls for donation of people and organizations in the country and abroad in order to give free of charge for the residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325130014/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy, the whole country remains 'red' according to the traffic light system.     Students require a My Vaccine Pass to attend classes, lectures, labs, workshops, tutorials and meetings in person. They can access research spaces, student support and advisory services. Other levels of education are open but with health measures in place. Capacity at all educational levels is based on 1-metre distancing.    Tertiary students who do not have My Vaccine Pass may make alternative learning arrangements with their educational institution.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305153246/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/traffic-lights-map/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210181000/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/education-at-red/tertiary-education-at-red/

21/3/22  Close prpoximity businesses are only open to people with a My Vaccine Pass    If you have a My Vaccine Pass, you can visit a close-proximity business, such as a hairdresser.  You must wear a face mask when you visit a close-proximity business.  Workers working at close-proximity businesses must wear a face mask.  Scan the QR code or keep a record of where you go.  If you are unwell, are isolating or waiting for the results of a COVID-19 test, call and reschedule your appointment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321103028/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/shopping-and-services-at-red/close-proximity-businesses-at-red/

No change in policies      Close proximity businesses are only open to people with a My Vaccine Pass  If you have a My Vaccine Pass, you can visit a close-proximity business, such as a hairdresser.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321103028/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/shopping-and-services-at-red/close-proximity-businesses-at-red/

Events are limited to 100 people if everyone has a My Vaccine Pass.  Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.  Compulsory Face masks should be worn at an event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215072048/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

Events can go ahead with My Vaccine Pass.  Indoor events are limited to 200 people. There are no capacity limits outdoors.  Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404102339/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

21/3/22  Gatherings can go ahead.  Gatherings are limited to 100 people if everyone has a My Vaccine Pass.  Gatherings are limited to 25 people if My Vaccine Passes are not being used.  Children and babies are included in the gathering limits â but not people working at a gathering.  You do not need to wear a face mask at a gathering when your gathering is the only one using the defined space and other people cannot mix with your guests.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312005342mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red/

Gatherings can go ahead.  If everyone has a My Vaccine Pass, indoor gatherings are limited to 200 people, and outdoor gatherings have no limit.  If My Vaccine Passes are not being used, indoor and outdoor gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Children and babies are included in the gathering limits â but not people working at a gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404103324/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red//

You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.  You can travel for any reason.  Unless your transport provider requires it, you do not need a My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test to travel.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321113919/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

You do not need a My Vaccine Pass to use public transport or taxi and ride-share services.  There are no physical distancing requirements on public transport, or at bus stops or train stations.  You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404103847/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

Without My Vaccine Pass, there are restrictions.  You can travel anywhere in New Zealand for any reason, and see friends and whanau.   With My Vaccine Pass, most parts of life continue as usual. You can visit cafes and bars, attend gatherings and events, and go to the hairdresser and gym.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321115624/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

21/3/22  21/3/22  Travellers from countries other than Australia banned    Fully vaccinated eligible travellers will no longer self-isolate  Advice from the Strategic COVID-19 Public Health Advisory Group and the Director General of Health is that it is now appropriate to drop the requirement for self-isolation for fully vaccinated travellers after they arrive in New Zealand.    Cabinet has agreed to lift all self-isolation requirements for vaccinated travellers entering New Zealand from 11:59pm on Wednesday 2 March 2022. That means New Zealand citizens and other eligible travellers entering the country will be able to step off the plane and immediately connect with family and friends and enjoy all New Zealand has to offer.    Caution has served us well during the past 2 years and as we continue to move through the Omicron outbreak and peak, we will continue to remove restrictions when advised it is safe to do so â as we always said we would.    Now that we are 2 years into the COVID-19 pandemic, the risk has shifted from our border to our community. As the pandemic evolves, we are too. Getting tested is now quicker and easier, requirements for isolation have been simplified to those who share a household, and care in the community is focused towards those most in need of support.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215081617/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/new-zealand-border-to-reopen-in-stages-from-27-february/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321101923/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/self-isolation-requirements-removed-step-2-brought-forward/

From 11:59pm 18 March 2022, most travellers entering New Zealand will be able to self-test on arrival and will no longer need to enter Managed Isolation and Quarantine (MIQ).  These travellers are now no longer required to enter MIQ when they arrive in New Zealand: unvaccinated New Zealand citizens ,   non-New Zealand citizens who meet the vaccination requirements to enter New Zealand, unless they are exempt.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220404110909/https://covid19.govt.nz/international-travel/travel-to-new-zealand/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220404110715/https://covid19.govt.nz/international-travel/leaving-new-zealand/

The following Measures apply to all Provinces:  a. Venues or parts of venues that operate as a restaurant or for food consumption on-premises may operate subject to:  1. all persons on entry and exit from venues must wash their hands with soap or hand sanitizer, and follow all other hygiene standards as issued by the Controller.  b. Venues or parts of venues that provide gambling activities and services may open if they ensure strict adherence to the COVID-19 safety guidelines issued by the Controller in relation to operating a gambling activity and service.  c. No licensed premises shall sell takeaway alcohol on Friday, Saturday, or Sunday, except restaurants that may continue to serve alcohol as regulated by their liquor license. The Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG) reduced the Kina Facility Rate (KFR) â the main policy rate - by 200 basis points to 3 percent from 5 percent and asked the commercial banks to reduce their respective Indicative Lending Rates. BPNG also reduced the Cash Reserve Requirement to 7 percent from 10 percent to provide additional liquidity to the commercial banks. All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

All people must wear masks in the entire country whenever going outside.  The following persons are exempted from these Measures:  a. Children under 12;  b. Persons with underlying medical conditions which inhibit their ability to wear a Mask or Face Covering, including persons with physical or mental illness or impairment, or disability  c. Persons who are unable to place or remove a Mask or Face Covering without assistance;  d. Persons undergoing dental treatment or other medical care to the extent that the procedure requires that no face covering may be worn;  e. Persons within an area of work designated for them and not for public access, and who can work in an environment whereby they are a minimum of 2 meters from any other person;  f. no coding changes for the period of 08-12 March 2022.    Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111938/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapore-to-simplify-covid-19-rules-from-march-15-including-allowing-five-household-visitors-at-a-time  __________________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 07 March 2022:  no coding changes for the period of 27 Feb - 07 Mar 2022.    Easing and streamlining of current covid measures to be delayed further as cases remain high.    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: The streamlining of COVID-19 safe management measures will be postponed again as daily local case numbers have remained high.  "The number of cases currently hospitalised also remains high, and our healthcare workers are still under significant pressure," said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Friday (Mar 4)."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220307093838/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-streamlining-safe-management-measures-delay-moh-high-case-numbers-2539831  _______________________  *** Please refer to notes dated 26 Feb 2022:  no coding changes for the period of 23-26 Feb 2022.  ____________________  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:  no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection
